results.title: Wallace & Gromit: the wrong trousers (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Christopher Moll, BBC-TV and Nick Park
results.brief_description: Once again our plasticine heroes are plunged into a hilarious tale of skullduggery involving an extraordinary pair of automated trousers and a villanous penguin. Posing as an innocent lodger, the fiendish fish-eater sets about recruiting mild-mannered Wallace as unwitting accomplice to his dastardly plot; a diamond heist. It is left to the faithful Gromit to turn detective and save the day as malice and mayhem culminate in a breathless train chase around the sitting room.

results.title: Wallace & Gromit: a grand day out
results.brief_description: Wallace likes a nice bit of cheese with his crackers, so when the eccentric inventor finds his fridge empty and the local corner shop shut for Bank Holiday, he is forced to look further afield for his cheddar. His faithful dog Gromit is used to his master’s flights of fancy, but this time his ears prick up with excitement as the two plasticene heroes blast off in their home-made rocket on the ultimate day-trip to the Moon! For children and adults alike, the animation techniques used in this production are quite incredible.

results.title: Wall of fear
results.brief_description: A widow, her son and mother newly settled in new location is terrified by a hoodlum, whom she had earlier humiliated in front of a crows od younger kids, when she slapped his face after she caught him ill-treating a younger boy. Her efforts to enlist the aid of the police, and others, are fruitless, she takes into her own hands, obtains a revolver, catches the terrorist in her son’s bedroom. The subsequent scenes show how she obtained a new friend. Cast includes; Susan Douglas, Eleanor Beecroft, Douglas Master, Jena Keller and herb Fisher.

results.title: Walking with dinosaurs [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Tim Haines, TV Asahi, Discovery Channel and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Walking with dinosaurs”.
Imagine if you could witness a Cretaceous sunset, watch as insectivorous pterosaurs chase moths in the evening, and bull triceratops lock horns over a young female. This is no longer a dream. “Walking with dinosaurs” is a six episode series that transports the viewer back to prehistoric times when dinosaurs ruled the earth. Using CGI animation, all the major eras - Triassic, Jurassic and Cretaceous - are faithfully recreated with stunning authenticity as classic natural history techniques meld with state of the art computer graphics. Filmed against spectacular natural backdrops in Chile, Tasmania and New Zealand and narrated by Kenneth Branagh, this series sets new standards for TV production and striked a perfect balance between information and entertainment. In addition to the six, 30 minute episodes is a behind the scenes look at the technological and labour intesive work that went into place to make the series possible. Individual episodes include; “New blood”, “A Time of titans”, “Cruel sea”, “Giant of the skies”, “Spirits of the ice forest” and “Death of a dynasty”. Comprehensive website at www.bbc.co.uk/dinosaurs. Also available on VHS [310597], [310599], [310598], “Making of” [310593].

results.title: Walking with cavemen: with Robert Winston
results.creator_credit: Peter Georgi, BBC, Discovery Channel, ProSieben and Richard Dale
results.brief_description: From the same team that produced “The Human Body” comes another fascinating and well-made documentary series presented by Robert Winston. In a four part series all on the same DVD, the history of human evolution from ancient apes to the present modern man is traversed in chronological order. Starting with ‘The First Ancestors’ the first ape from Africa to stand on two legs is discovered. Using the latest ‘animatic’ technology the viewer is privy to the ancient world and these creatures using a mixture of computer generated images and actors in monkey suits - done in a style that makes for compelling viewing. Not only physical traits but also the lifestyle of Neanderthal man is shown. The series climaxes with the discovery of one key element that makes modern man different - the gift of imagination.

results.title: Walking with beasts [DVD]
results.brief_description: 65 million years ago the reign of the dinosaur ended. This BBC series is about what happened next. Nearly every creature over ten kilograms had been wiped out, leaving little creatures, like mammals to flourish. Mammals eventually took over the world over the next 20 million years, laying claim to earth and sea. This series presents the evolution of a multitude of mammals - exotic creatures such as the leptictidium, ambulocetus, dinofelis, gastronis, basilosaurus and the moeritherium, to name a few. Mastery of computer-generated images and animation, coupled with an atmospheric soundtrack, makes for colourful and realistic re-creations of the ways in which these magnificent animals operated in their fertile environments. Divided into six episodes - New dawn, Whale killer, Land of giants, Next of kin, Sabre tooth and Mammoth journey - each section focuses on a different type of mammal, covering such topics as species development, predators, laws of the animal kingdom, habits, habitats and changes to the earth’s ecosystems. At times this spectacular work, with its entertaining and gripping visuals, is capable of depicting graphically gory predatory behaviour. Also covers the age of the Neanderthal, and early stages of man versus beast. The breadth of background research is evident - awe-inspiring visuals are coupled with an informative and entertaining commentary. Narrated by Kenneth Branagh.

results.title: Walking the mob
results.creator_credit: Keith Fraser, ABC-TV (Australia) and Lionel Hudson
results.brief_description: The life and work of the cattle drovers shown as they take a big herd across central Australia. The drover’s way of lie in the outback Australia. A typical drover, Jack Jones, and his team bring a mob of 600 cattle from Bergmont Station in the Northern Territory to Longreach, Queensland. Their route follows the Thompson River, one of the country’s driest regions. Shows new and old methods of transporting cattle; one lot being walked and the other lot by train.

results.title: Walking in a sacred manner: North American indians and the natural world
results.creator_credit: Stephen Cross, Tapovana Films, Derek Waterman and Tom McBride
results.brief_description: Told in their own words, this film provides a commentary on the American Indians’ way of life prior to the erosion of their cultural values by European civilization. Highlights their respect for the natural world and their appreciation of its importance to the physical, spiritual and psychological well-being of human beings. Photographs taken by Edward S. Curtis between 1896 and 1930 illustrate the traditional life of the Northwest plains and mountain Indians in its complete, authentic form. The commentary is selected from the words of: Black Elk, Brave Buffalo, Chief Flying Hawk, Chief Luther-Standing Bear, Chief Red Jacket, Chief Seattle. Music from “Songs and Dances of the Flathead Indians” and John Arlee.
